snippet: Twenty-one people had been sentenced to death for their roles in the deadly 2012 soccer riot that killed more than 70 people in the city of Port Said.
abstract: Many in Port Said, Egypt, declare they now believe that a military coup might be the best hope to restore order after a court ruling sentencing twenty-one people to death for their roles in deadly 2012 soccer riot causes yet another riot.

byline.original: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and KAREEM FAHIM
byline.contributor: David D. Kirkpatrick reported from Port Said, and Kareem Fahim from Cairo. Mayy El Sheikh contributed reporting from Port Said.

lead_paragraph: Twenty-one people had been sentenced to death for their roles in the deadly 2012 soccer riot that killed more than 70 people in the city of Port Said.

headline.seo: As Egypt’s Security Crisis Deepens After Verdict, Calls for a Coup
headline.main: As Crisis Deepens in Egypt After Ruling on Riot, Calls for a Military Coup
headline.print_headline: As Crisis Deepens in Egypt After Ruling on Riot, Some Seek Military Rule
